citation.article-title: Geobacillus debilis sp. nov., a novel obligately thermophilic bacterium isolated from a cool soil environment, and reassignment of Bacillus pallidus to Geobacillus pallidus comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Geobacillus debilis sp. nov.
Geobacillus debilis (de′bil.is. L. masc. adj. debilis weak or feeble, referring to the restricted substrate range for this species).
Gram-negative rods, 0·5–1·0 μm wide by 1·0–14·0 μm long, motile, spores sparsely produced terminally, sporangium not swollen.
Colonies flat, cream-coloured with smooth margins.
Growth occurs at 50–70 °C, with an optimum above 60 °C.
The DNA G+C content is 49·9 mol%.
Production of acid from raffinose and trehalose, and also from ribose, sorbitol and arabinose in some strains.
No utilization of starch but casein and gelatin used in some strains; very limited use of alkanes.
The type strain is TfT (=DSM 16016T=NCIMB 13995T); strains have been isolated from 50 mm undisturbed subsurface soil samples from Northern Ireland.
